text: set the channel topic: ask an anonymous question here → <https://airtable.com/shrgX8UCcFDmmnRS5>

Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: mid (4-7 years of experience)

"I've recently accepted a remote job offer at an SF-based content agency. I'm based in a part of Europe where salaries are much lower than in the States. 

The job I got pays really well (about 10x more than the average yearly salary in my country) BUT I feel I'm unfairly paid when compared to my peers that do the exact same work as me producing work of the same quality as me. 

I'm just wondering what to do? I don't want to change jobs as I'm quite satisfied with every other aspect here except for the pay, as I believe I'm very underpaid for the work I do (about 60% less)."
I second <@U02ME33ACS3> on HubSpot's courses. Ahrefs also has some amazing content on SEO.

elements.text: I second
on HubSpot's courses. Ahrefs also has some amazing content on SEO.

text:
Personally, I don’t see a ton of side content gigs doing more than giving you more writing experience. I haven’t seen a ton of strategy focused roles. Plus, that sounds exhausting.

Here’s a few ideas:
1. Look for mentors who can help you gain strategic chops. You could also use professional development budget to pay a coach who specializes in this. (Maybe? Hopefully?)
2. What strategy work do you want to do? Can you make some space and time to make it happen at your current company? (even if it isn’t anyone’s priority.) Then present that work in interviews? This would be easier to me than finding a side hustle that’s strategic.
3. For sure look for courses (if you can find one that feels right), but even going through/using templates and frameworks that already exists and applying them to your current work would help you get there. (Look at content marketing institute to start--although I’m sure plenty of people here have more options to offer!). Same with going through all the process/strategic content SEO vendors have already shared for free. 
4. Start sharing your strategic insights and learnings publicly so you’re see as a strategic leader--even if you don’t feel like one internally. 
Best of luck!

text:
Hmm, that's sticky. 60% less is crazy. Could be exploitative. In which case, broaching the topic could be politically risky.

But! Given your experience overall AND your newfound stateside experience, I'd start to browse around for other jobs. I know you don't want to switch... but shopping around won't hurt, right?

Going into new potential offers, you can use your research re: pay grades to negotiate for a salary that works for you. You may be able to use an offer to leverage a comparable pay bump at your current place.

The other option is to take the issue up with the current employer. If they are truly great in all others aspects, maybe they're open to the conversation. Though if not, then maybe they aren't so hot to work for after all...

text:
That does sound like a huge disparity. Only thing that makes sense is the pay is done on a location basis, in which case I'd try to find out what formula they're using for that to make sure it's properly weighted (60% lower still sounds like a big difference even if a company had a system like that).

If there's no such salary formula, I'd bring it up in a 1:1, and have evidence to show that you're performing on the same level as your coworkers.

text:
So, I have been thinking about this a lot. And it has really got  to me - after quitting my full-time job. How can freelance writer scale from $5k each month to 10?

Like - I know experience matters - and I hold a 7+ years experience helping businesses refine their messaging. But - the only problem is - businesses are always on the lookout for Native writers.

So - here I am - wondering how to scale your Freelance copywriting business? What's your approach?

elements.text:

Like - I know experience matters - and I hold a 7+ years experience helping businesses refine their messaging. But - the only problem is - businesses are always on the lookout for Native writers.

So - here I am - wondering how to scale your Freelance copywriting business? What's your approach?

text:
Logically, there are only two things you can do to affect your income if you’re only focusing on writing project:
• Charge more
• Work more
One of those is going to be more feasible than the others, but you can do both.

Other potential ways to increase income are hiring others to subcontract while charging higher rates (agency model) or coming up with a passive income like a training program that people buy from Udemy

elements.text: Logically, there are only two things you can do to affect your income if you’re only focusing on writing project:

Work more

One of those is going to be more feasible than the others, but you can do both.

Other potential ways to increase income are hiring others to subcontract while charging higher rates (agency model) or coming up with a passive income like a training program that people buy from Udemy

text: If you’re encountering challenges selling to your current customers/market, maybe you can try changing markets to a different industry/geolocation/specialization?

elements.text: If you’re encountering challenges selling to your current customers/market, maybe you can try changing markets to a different industry/geolocation/specialization?

text:
Also, the main issue is reaching out to businesses.

So, quick ques - what does your outreach funnel look like?

text: truth to be told, most of my work comes from referrals now. but a few years ago, my outreach funnel was very inconsistent. i wasn’t promoting myself online and i did a poor job cold calling

text: i relied a lot on relationships (still do)

text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: senior (8+ years)

"Despite my 8 years of content marketing experience, most of my roles that were supposed to be strategic ended up being purely production (churning out a high volume of blog posts dictated by the leadership team and putting out various fires, for example). I'm finally in a role where I'm leading content strategy and I'm having serious imposter syndrome. Any advice or resources to brush up my skills would be very much appreciated!"

If you enjoy podcasts, I’ve been loving The Long Game, a content podcast by Omniscient Digital. It’s really conversational and they have great topics (and debates) about content goals, strategy, collab with other teams, etc. It’s a great resource for learning and building a POV on different elements of content strategy. Some Good Content, and of course Superpath, are also great paid resources—which you may be able to have covered by your company.

If you are job searching right now, please tell me a bit about your experience thus far. I will send you a copy of the results of my survey. Thanks!
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfiBiWL1zaKCHggebsmpcCHjC7o9KbKEa3xOEkVX05T_JgUaA/viewform?usp=sf_link>

elements.text: If you are job searching right now, please tell me a bit about your experience thus far. I will send you a copy of the results of my survey. Thanks!

text:
Dear Imposter Syndrome — adding more skills is never a bad thing, but it might not resolve your imposter syndrome. IS is very common, esp when one starts a new job. I would suggest a couple other things to help you challenge that inner critic voice (that says stuff like: ‘you aren’t good enough for this job. you are over your skis.’)

1. Remind yourself of all you know --- fill your work space with evidence of your good work, skill and expertise (the thank you notes, the awards, the credentials, etc. — sometimes we forget our good stuff.)
2. Put some post notes up at your computer monitor — ‘they hired me because….. fill in the blank.’   Sometimes organizations hire people that bring a different range of experiences — in strategic organizations this is a power move. 
3. Reach out to a trusted professional contact that you have worked with before --- tell them how you are feeling — and ask them to help you reconnect to what you are awesome at. We rarely see our Zone of Genius without someone else there to reflect it back. Our best stuff is often stuff we come by naturally to a degree — and it may not feel special because we didn’t have to work super duper hard for it. 
4. Stay aligned to your new boss --- check in for feedback — “what are three things I’m doing well here.”  “what are three things you want me to get better at.” 
Remember when you start a new job — you are at the bottom of an S curve — and learning about how to navigate and apply your skills. Rising on the S curve can take time — 6 to 12 months even… be patient.
